Software APIs

C functions

Common functions

Functions

void enable_user_interface()

Enable comunication between software and user project

Warning

This necessary when reading or writing are needed between wishbone and user project if interface isn’t enabled no ack would be recieve and the writing or reading command will be stuck

void enable_hk_spi(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable the housekeeping SPI This function writes to the housekeeping disenable register inside the housekeeping

Note

When this register asserted housekeeping SPI can’t be used and gpios [3] which is CSB can be used as anyother housekeeping gpio

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) housekeeping is active, 0 (false) housekeeping is disabled

void dummy_delay(int num)

Insert delay

Parameters:

num – number of delays steps. step is increment local variable and check it’s value

GPIO

Enums

enum gpio_mode

GPIOs possible modes

Values:

enumerator GPIO_MODE_MGMT_STD_INPUT_NOPULL

Managment input with no pull (floating is read as Z)

enumerator GPIO_MODE_MGMT_STD_INPUT_PULLDOWN

Managment input pull-down (floating is read as 0)

enumerator GPIO_MODE_MGMT_STD_INPUT_PULLUP

Managment input pull-up (floating is read as 1)

enumerator GPIO_MODE_MGMT_STD_OUTPUT

Managment output

enumerator GPIO_MODE_MGMT_STD_BIDIRECTIONAL

Managment bi-direction

enumerator GPIO_MODE_MGMT_STD_ANALOG

Managment Ananlog

enumerator GPIO_MODE_USER_STD_INPUT_NOPULL

User input with no pull (floating is read as Z)

enumerator GPIO_MODE_USER_STD_INPUT_PULLDOWN

User input pull-down (floating is read as 0)

enumerator GPIO_MODE_USER_STD_INPUT_PULLUP

User input pull-up (floating is read as 1)

enumerator GPIO_MODE_USER_STD_OUTPUT

User output

enumerator GPIO_MODE_USER_STD_BIDIRECTIONAL

User bi-direction

enumerator GPIO_MODE_USER_STD_OUT_MONITORED

User Monitor same as output

enumerator GPIO_MODE_USER_STD_ANALOG

User Ananlog

Functions

void configure_all_gpios(enum gpio_mode config)

Configure all gpio with the config

Note

These configurations will not be change the GPIOs modes until calling gpio_config_load()

Parameters:

config – is configuration of type gpio_mode

void gpio_config_load()

Load the configurations changes to the GPIOs

void configure_gpio(int gpio_num, enum gpio_mode config)

Configure one gpio with the input config

Note

These configurations will not be change the GPIOs modes until calling gpio_config_load()

Parameters:

  • config – is configuration of type gpio_mode

  • gpio_num – is gpio number it can have values from 0 to 37

void set_gpio_l(unsigned int data)

Write to the low 32 GPIOs GPIOS[31:0]

Examples:

  • set_gpio_l(0x1); // write 1 to gpio[0] and write 0 in the remaining 31 gpios  


  • set_gpio_l(0x5); // write 1 to gpio[0] and gpio[3] and write 0 in the remaining 30 gpios

Note

For writing by this function to be seen at the GPIO the GPIO has to be configured as managment output

Parameters:

data – is the data sent to the GPIOs

void set_gpio_h(unsigned int data)

Write to the highest 6 GPIOs GPIOS[37:32]

Examples:

  • set_gpio_h(0x1); // write 1 to gpio[32] and write 0 in the remaining 5 gpios 


  • set_gpio_h(0x5); // write 1 to gpio[32] and 34 and write 0 in the remaining 4 gpios

Note

For writing by this function to be seen at the GPIO the GPIO has to be configured as managment output

Parameters:

data – is the data sent to the GPIOs

void set_gpio(long data)

Write to the 38 GPIOs GPIOS[37:0]

Examples:

  • set_gpio(0x1); // write 1 to gpio[0] and write 0 in the remaining 37 gpios  


  • set_gpio(0x5); // write 1 to gpio[0] and gpio[3] and write 0 in the remaining 36 gpios 


  • set_gpio(0x100000000); // write 1 to gpio[32] and write 0 in the remaining 36 gpios

Todo:

verify this function

Note

For writing by this function to be seen at the GPIO the GPIO has to be configured as managment output

Parameters:

data – is the data sent to the GPIOs

unsigned int get_gpio_h()

Read the highest 6 GPIOs GPIOS[37:32]

Note

For Reading value from the GPIOs, the GPIO should configure as managment input. otherwise 0 would be read

unsigned int get_gpio_l()

Read low 32 GPIOs GPIOS[31:0]

Note

For Reading value from the GPIOs, the GPIO should configure as managment input. otherwise 0 would be read

void wait_gpio_l(unsigned int data)

wait over the lowest 32 gpios to equal the data passed

Examples:

  • wait_gpio_l(0x1); // function would return only when gpio[0]==1 and rest of 31 gpios = 0  


  • wait_gpio_l(0x5); // function would return only when gpio[0]==1 and gpio[3]==1 and rest of 30 gpios = 0

Note

For writing by this function to be seen at the GPIO the GPIO has to be configured as managment output

Parameters:

data – is the data that should wait until sent to the GPIOs

void wait_gpio_h(unsigned int data)

wait over the higest 6 gpios to equal the data passed

Examples:

  • wait_gpio_h(0x1); // function would return only when gpio[32]==1 and rest of 5 gpios = 0  


  • wait_gpio_h(0x5); // function would return only when gpio[32]==1 and gpio[34]==1 and rest of 4 gpios = 0

Note

For writing by this function to be seen at the GPIO the GPIO has to be configured as managment output

Parameters:

data – is the data that should wait until sent to the GPIOs

void wait_gpio_l_masked(unsigned int data, unsigned int mask)

wait over the masked lowest 32 gpios to equal the data passed

Examples:

  • wait_gpio_l_masked(0x1,0xF); // function would return only when gpio[0]==1 and gpio[3:1]==0 and don't care about the rest of gpios  


  • wait_gpio_l_masked(0x5,0x7); // function would return only when gpio[0]==1 and gpio[3]==1 and gpio[2]==0 and don't care about the rest of gpios

Note

For writing by this function to be seen at the GPIO the GPIO has to be configured as managment output

Parameters:

  • data – is the data that should wait until sent to the GPIOs

  • mask – mask over the each GPIO if the mask value is 0 the this gpio value are ignored

void wait_gpio_h_masked(unsigned int data, unsigned int mask)

wait over the masked higest 6 gpios to equal the data passed

Examples:

  • wait_gpio_h_masked(0x1,0xF); // function would return only when gpio[32]==1 and gpio[35:33]==0 and don't care about the rest of gpios  


  • wait_gpio_h_masked(0x5,0x7); // function would return only when gpio[32]==1 and gpio[34]==1 and gpio[33]==0 and don't care about the rest of gpios

Note

For writing by this function to be seen at the GPIO the GPIO has to be configured as managment output

Parameters:

  • data – is the data that should wait until sent to the GPIOs

  • mask – mask over the each GPIO if the mask value is 0 the this gpio value are ignored

Interrupts

Functions

void enable_external1_irq(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable external1 interrupt GPIO[7]

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) interrupt is active and software would detect if happened, 0 (false) interrupt is disabled and software would not detect if happened

void enable_external2_irq(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable external2 interrupt GPIO[12]

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) interrupt is active and software would detect if happened, 0 (false) interrupt is disabled and software would not detect if happened

void enable_timer0_irq(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable timer0 interrupt

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) interrupt is active and software would detect if happened, 0 (false) interrupt is disabled and software would not detect if happened

void enable_uart_tx_irq(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable uart tx interrupt

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) interrupt is active and software would detect if happened, 0 (false) interrupt is disabled and software would not detect if happened

void enable_uart_rx_irq(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable uart rx interrupt

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) interrupt is active and software would detect if happened, 0 (false) interrupt is disabled and software would not detect if happened

void enable_hk_spi_irq(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable spi interrupt

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) interrupt is active and software would detect if happened, 0 (false) interrupt is disabled and software would not detect if happened

Logic analyzers

Enums

enum la_reg_number

Logic analyzers registers

Values:

enumerator LA_REG_0

First LA register probs [31:0]

enumerator LA_REG_1

Second LA register probs [63:32]

enumerator LA_REG_2

Third LA register probs [95:64]

enumerator LA_REG_3

First LA register probs [127:96]

Functions

void set_la_ien(enum la_reg_number reg_num, unsigned int is_enable)

Setting logic analyzer input enable

Enable as input to the user project. Software sends to user prject

Parameters:

  • reg_num – logic analyzer register to write to. Usually not all caravel versions has the same numbers of LA registers They might have 4 registers (128 probs between software and user project) or registers (64 probs between software and user project)

  • is_enable – 32 bits each bit indicate if the corresponding prob enabled as input

void set_la_oen(enum la_reg_number reg_num, unsigned int is_enable)

Setting logic analyzer output enable

Enable as output from the user project. Software receieves from user prject

Parameters:

  • reg_num – logic analyzer register to write to. Usually not all caravel versions has the same numbers of LA registers They might have 4 registers (128 probs between software and user project) or registers (64 probs between software and user project)

  • is_enable – 32 bits each bit indicate if the corresponding prob enabled as output

void set_la_reg(enum la_reg_number reg_num, unsigned int data)

Write data through logic analyers from software to user project

Note

For this to work correctly prob should be configured as output

Parameters:

  • reg_num – logic analyzer register to write to. Usually not all caravel versions has the same numbers of LA registers They might have 4 registers (128 probs between software and user project) or registers (64 probs between software and user project)

  • data – data to write through logic analyzers

unsigned int get_la_reg(enum la_reg_number reg_num)

Read data through logic analyers from user projectt to software

Note

For this to work correctly prob should be configured as output

Parameters:

reg_num – logic analyzer register to read from. Usually not all caravel versions has the same numbers of LA registers They might have 4 registers (128 probs between software and user project) or registers (64 probs between software and user project)

Managment GPIO

Functions

void mgmt_gpio_i_enable()

Configure managment GPIO as input

void mgmt_gpio_o_enable()

Configure managment GPIO as outpur

void mgmt_gpio_io_enable()

Configure managment GPIO as bi-direction

void mgmt_gpio_io_disable()

Configure managment GPIO as floating It’s not connected as input or output

void mgmt_gpio_wr(bool data)

Write data in managment GPIO

Note

This function works when managment GPIO configured as output

Parameters:

data – data to write at managment GPIO possbile values are 0 and 1

int mgmt_gpio_rd()

Read data in managment GPIO

Note

This function works correctly when managment GPIO configured as input If managment doesn’t connect to anything the software would read “0”

void wait_gpio_mgmt(bool data)

Wait over managment GPIO to equal data

Note

This function works correctly when managment GPIO configured as input

Parameters:

data – data to wait over

SPI master

Functions

void spi_write(char c)

Write byte (8bits) through SPI master

Parameters:

c – byte to write range 0x0 to 0xFF

char spi_read()

Read byte (8bits) through SPI master

void enable_spi(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable the master spi

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) master spi is active, 0 (false) master spi is disabled

void enable_CS(bool is_enable)

assert or deassert chip select

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) chip select is asserted, 0 (false) chip select is deasserted

Timer0

Functions

void timer0_oneshot_configure(unsigned int count)

Start Timer in oneshot count down mode start value is count

Parameters:

count – start value in the counter > 0

void timer0_periodic_configure(unsigned int count)

Start counter in periodic count down mode start value is count

Timer will roll over to the caount value when it reachs 0

Parameters:

count – start value in the counter > 0

void enable_timer0(bool is_enable)

Enable or Disable timer0

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1 (true) timer0 is enable (start counting), 0 (false) timer0 is disabled

unsigned int get_timer0_val()

Get timer current value

UART

Functions

void enable_uart_TX(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable TX of uart

Note

Some caravel CPU enable and disable uart TX and RX together

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1(true) uart TX enable, 0 (false) uart TX disable

void uart_RX_enable(bool is_enable)

Enable or disable RX of uart

Note

Some caravel CPU enable and disable uart TX and RX together

Parameters:

is_enable – when 1(true) uart RX enable, 0 (false) uart RX disable

char uart_getc()

Wait receiving ASCII symbol and return it.

Return the first ASCII symbol of the UART recieved queue

RX mode have to be enabled

void uart_pop_char()

Pop the first ASCII symbol of the UART recieved queue

uart_getc() function would keeping reading the same symbol unless this function is called

void print(const char *p)

Send ASCII symbol or symbols through UART

TX mode have to be enabled

User Address Space

Functions

void write_user_double_word(unsigned int data, int offset)

Write double word (4 bytes) at user address space 32 bit register

address

offset

byte0

byte1

byte2

byte3

0x0

0

0

1

2

3

0x4

1

4

5

6

7

0x8

2

8

9

10

11

0xC

3

12

13

14

15

Note

if user space address length is 4 bits address that mean it has 2^4 bytes = 16 bytes that mean it has only 4 doublewords. In this case offset would take values from 0 to 3.

Typically address space is 26 address bits which mean it has 67,108,864 bytes = 16,777,216 doubleword In this case offset would take values from 0 to 16,777,215.

Parameters:

  • data – double world data to write

  • offset – the offset of the register to write. Origin at the user project address

void write_user_word(unsigned short data, unsigned int offset, bool is_first_word)

Write word (2 bytes) at user address space 32 bit register

is first word

Note

if user space address length is 4 bits address that mean it has 2^4 bytes = 16 bytes that mean it has only 8 words. In this case offset would take values from 0 to 3 and is_first_word can take 0 or 1.

Typically address space is 26 address bits which mean it has 67,108,864 bytes = 33,554,432 doubleword In this case offset would take values from 0 to 16,777,215 and is_first_word can take 0 or 1.

Parameters:

  • data – world data to write

  • offset – the offset of the register to write. Origin at the user project address

  • is_first_word – the offset of the register to write. Origin at the user project address
